metadata.case_name: Sales Tax Officer, Banaras & Ors. v. Respondent Firm

facts.text: The respondent is a firm registered under the Indian Partnership Act dealing in Bullion, Gold and Silver ornaments and forward contracts in Silver Bullion at Banaras in the State of Uttar Pradesh.
For the assessment years 1948-49, 1949-50 and 1950-51 the Sales Tax Officer, Banaras (appellant No. 1) assessed the respondent to U. P. Sales Tax on its forward transactions in Silver Bullion.

The respondent had deposited the sums of Rs. 150-12-0, Rs. 470-0-0 and Rs. 741-0-0 for the said three years which sums were appropriated towards the payment of the sales tax liability under assessment orders passed on May 31, 1949, October 30, 1950 and August 22, 1951.
The levy of sales tax on forward transactions was held to be ultra vires by the High Court of Allahabad on February 27, 1952, in Messrs. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash v. Sales Tax Officer, Kanpur.
The respondent by letter dated July 8, 1952, asked for a refund of the amounts of sales tax paid.
The Commissioner of Sales Tax, U. P. (appellant No. 2) by letter dated July 19, 1952, refused to refund the same.

The respondent filed Civil Misc. Writ Petition No. 355 of 1952 under Art. 226 of the Constitution asking for writ of certiorari quashing the three assessment orders and writ of mandamus for refund of Rs. 1,365-12-0.
Judgment of Allahabad High Court in Budh Prakash confirmed by Supreme Court on May 3, 1954, in Sales Tax Officer, Pilibhit v. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash.
Chaturvedi J. by order dated November 30, 1954, quashed the assessment orders in so far as they related to forward contracts and issued writ of mandamus directing refund.
Appellants filed Special Appeal No. 18 of 1955, dismissed by Division Bench on December 1, 1955.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(b) on July 30, 1956, on undertaking by Advocate-General that State will pay costs.
Advocate-General before High Court stated that amounts paid under mistake of law irrecoverable and did not contend that respondent ought to have proceeded otherwise than by writ under Art. 226.

legal_issues.text: Whether s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act applies to the facts of the present case, particularly to money paid under a mistake of law for sales tax on forward transactions held ultra vires.

petitioner_arguments.text: The respondent ought to have followed procedure of appeal or revision under U.P. Sales Tax Act and writ petition would not lie for refund.
Money paid under mistake of law is irrecoverable, analogous to English, American and Australian law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.72 Indian Contract Act; English law (Kerr on Fraud and Mistake; Rogers v. Ingham); American (Willoughby); Australian (Werrin v. Commonwealth)

petitioner_arguments.text: Payments were voluntary without protest in discharge of tax liability under U.P. Sales Tax Act.
Monies received by State of U.P. had been spent away, disentitling recovery by estoppel or equitable considerations.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.72 Indian Contract Act (observations on circumstances disentitling recovery)

respondent_arguments.text: Entitled to refund under s.72 Indian Contract Act as payments made under mistake of law.

court_reasoning.text: Contentions on procedure not available due to categorical statement by Advocate-General before High Court that writ lay and no such point taken earlier.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Whole matter proceeded on basis that respondent entitled to recover via writ.

court_reasoning.text: s.72 applies to mistake of law as well as fact; term 'mistake' unqualified; interpret plain terms without reference to English law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Follows Bank of England v. Vagliano Brothers; Mohori Bibee; Satyabrata Ghose.

court_reasoning.text: Privy Council in Shiba Prasad Singh v. Srish Chandra Nundi resolved conflict: mistake in s.72 includes law; no inconsistency with s.21/22; payment not due entitles recovery.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Payment by mistake means thinking money due when not due.

court_reasoning.text: No distinction for tax payments; voluntary nature irrelevant if mistake established; no estoppel as common mistake of law by both parties.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State spending money does not disentitle; no equitable considerations override clear s.72.

court_reasoning.text: Payments deposited in advance and appropriated; both parties under mistake till SC confirmation on May 3, 1954.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Respondent's state of mind relevant; mistake established.

holdings.text: s.72 Indian Contract Act entitles recovery of money paid under mistake of law, including tax on ultra vires levy; applies even to voluntary payments without protest absent estoppel.

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash v. Sales Tax Officer, Kanpur
precedents_cited.relevance: Held levy of sales tax on forward transactions ultra vires.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sales Tax Officer, Pilibhit v. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash
precedents_cited.relevance: Confirmed Allahabad HC judgment on ultra vires levy.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shiba Prasad Singh v. Srish Chandra Nundi
precedents_cited.relevance: s.72 includes mistake of law; payment not due recoverable.
Interpret Contract Act plainly; no equity against statute.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bank of England v. Vagliano Brothers
precedents_cited.relevance: Examine statute language first, uninfluenced by prior law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Satyabrata Ghose v. Mugneeram Bangur Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Contract Act exhaustive; no import English principles.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jagdish Prasad Pannalal v. Produce Exchange Corporation Ltd.
Wolf Sons v. Dadyba Khimji Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held s.72 not apply to mistake of law; overruled by Privy Council.

precedents_cited.case_name: Appavoo Chettiar v. S.I. Ry. Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held s.72 not apply to mistake of law.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: s.72 requires repayment of money paid by mistake (law or fact) or coercion; no inconsistency with s.21/22.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Sales Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Assessments under Act on forward transactions held ultra vires; no bar to recovery under s.72.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition under Art.226; certificate under Art.133.

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed. The judgment and order of the High Court directing refund of Rs.1,365-12-0 paid as sales tax on forward transactions and costs is upheld.
outcome.relief_granted: Refund of amounts aggregating Rs. 1,365-12-0; costs.
outcome.costs: Appeal dismissed with costs; State undertook to pay costs as taxed by Supreme Court.

key_quotes.text: "A person to whom money has been paid, or anything delivered by mistake or under coercion, must repay or return it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of s.72 Indian Contract Act central to decision.

key_quotes.text: The term mistake has been used without any qualification or limitation whatever and comprises within its scope a mistake of law as well as a mistake of fact.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Payment by mistake in s. 72 must refer to a payment which was not legally due and which could not have been enforced the mistake is thinking that the money paid was due when, in fact, it was not due.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains scope post-Privy Council; distinguishes s.21.

key_quotes.text: Merely because the State of U. P. had not retained the monies paid by the respondent but had spent them away in the ordinary course of the business of the State would not make any difference.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects estoppel/equity based on state spending money.
